CatDescriptText: Miss Terri Grey, high school student, Sewickley and Mr. John White, steelworker, Duquesne, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 22, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you believe Negroes in Pittsburgh are as militant about Civil Rights like others of their race display in other Metropolitan areas in the USA? Why?"  Ms. Grey's answer reads: "...To a certain extent they are.  They realize we want freedom the same as Negroes in other areas.  I think the majority of Negroes in Pittsburgh are working together to secure first-class citizenship."  Mr. White's answer reads: "Not in Pittsburgh, like they are in New York City, Philadelphia and Washington, D.C. it seems as though Negroes here don't care."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Terri Grey wearing eyeglasses and light colored short sleeve shirt with scalloped collar, holding paper bags, standing on sidewalk, Downtown; Portrait of John White wearing light colored short sleeve shirt with eyeglasses and pens in left breast pocket, standing on sidewalk, Downtown
